titleStmt.title: M54, 3 of 11. [Anon: for coins. When he was walking...]. Typescript fragment, 4 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 3 of 11. [for coins. When he was walking...]. Typescript fragment, 4 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
for coins. When he was walking in xxx the garden, " the poor come kkocking (knocking) at the gate and my man says "Sir, there is some one at the gate would speak with oyuyou ()." So he laid aside his book and went out among the poor. He visited them in their hovels. He noted their poverty. He saw the poor man unable now to buy a goose, for the great lords were enclosing the fields. He went to the great man and found him still in bed, after his hunting anf hid (and his) hawking. He saw the poor sutis (suitors) waiting ho (hour) in the hall to get their suit herad (heard). These were the casees that he brought before In a voice that sumbles (stumbles) and uses the old language of his fathers house, ))" they say in my country to the hogs mingle mangle, cum pur, cum pur" --- he brought into the light of day the hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmx xmxmxmxmxmxxx the harlot going to execution at and saying as she went "that f (if) good fellows had kept touch with her, she had not bin at this time in that case." He saw the curates in their velevet (velvet) shoes and slippers meet to dance the morris dance. And the fine ladies dressed in vardinaglls (vardingalls) with their hair puffed out in tussocks He saw the yo ng (young) men given over in the s t to gulling drinm ig (drinking) and whoring. The young men dice away their thrift; Instead of shooting with the long ow (bow) they their sports are lost turned into bowling drinming (drinking) and whoring. He And the poor are still going on pilgrimages, setting up candles and
wirshipping (worshipping) pigs bones. [illeg.] He casts the light of the new learning upon the the old superstitions. He too, until he

thirty "had walked in the shadow of d ath (death)." It was Master at who ppened (opened) his eyes; Master Bilney who went about among the poor and the sivk (sick), Master Bilney heard him preach agianst (against) and his opinons. and desired me for Gods sake to hear his confessio (confession) "did so; and to say the very truth, by his confession I learnt ed more than for many yeares (yeares). With Bilney he vi ted (visited) the prisones (prisoners) in the Tower at Cambridge, for he was ever visig (visiting)
pirsoners (prisoners) andsick (and sick) folk. There was a woman who had killed her child. And brought her story before King as he talked with him after the sermon in the gallery. and he got her padrdon (pardon). Master Bilney was burnt; so it may wi be, he will be burnt. eanehile (Meanwhile) he will speak the truth so that the simp le (simple) can understand. In their own tongue. Standing on the verge of the Elizabetha (Elizabethan) age, he saw, as saw, the great buildings rise on the foundations of the old. "There ws (was) never such buildings then as if (is) now, planting, nor marrying." And yet the Englis (English) are still sunk in supe stition (superstition). Give thmoey (the money) he implores that was wont to bestow on pilgrimagesmatters (pilgrimages matters), in trentalls in masses, in purgatory matters" to poor men sons so that they may become schlars (scholars). "There be now none but greate mens sons in colleges." It will come to pass that
we shallhave (shall have) nothing but a little Ebglish (English) divinity, that will bring the realm into a very barbarousness, and utter decay of learning."

This was the voice of the new lraning (learning), the vo ce (voice) that ousted superstiti,n (superstition), the voice of reason, charity, common sense. But it was by an irnoy (irony) ironically enough, the

the preacher who was for banishing and such
supersitions (superstitions) was forging the very weapon theat (that) give the old
mibstrels (minstrels) a new lease of life. His English. When he said the at the beginning and at theend of his ermon (sermon) he was putting English intpo high places. He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching Spenser and Shakespere (Shakespeare) how to write.

Both Harrison and Latimer see the very same house [The house was being?] the hose (house) that was being built on the foundations of the old house. We can still see the great Elizabethan house whose building was to both preacher and antiquary a sign of txmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx luxury. in all its glory. There it is, standing in its green island of Park seapareted (separated) often from the high road by only a d p (dip) in the ground and a low red wall. With its congloeration (conglomeration) of roofs and chapels and chimeys (chimneys) i (it) dwarfs its neighboyrs (neighbours). Inside all is kept as if the Queen Elizabeth were expected. The upright Elizabetahn (Elizabethan) chairs stand round the walls. Their ftinges (fittings) and tapestry are not much faded. The great oak tables are heavy and polished. The carbed (carved) chairs and cupboards look barnd (brand) new. The floor is strewn with carpets; cut glass chandeliers hang down from the decorated pl ter (plaster) work on the celing (ceiling). Even knick knacks ha v (have) survived; the inlaid work box, the and the pear shaped l te (lute) on which the Queen once played.

But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only the furniture remains,, stiff and ornate, fantastic and
uncushioned (uncushioned).

Latimer had read the Lord (Lord's) Prayer in English. The Bible was printed in English. And, using the prose of the bible when they write prose, the Elixabethans (Elizabethans) are unknwon (unknown) to us. When in some extremity of anguish or fear they take up the pen they use the rhyms (rhythms) of the Bible. Itis (It is) a garment only to be worn when the mind is in the right attidtue (attitude). They can say nothing simple, subtle, or breif (brief). At Lady sat writing to . But her letters are like
seroms (sermons), or satte doucments (state documents), intricate, involved, circumtutious. She is a counsellor admonishing a subordinate; She e hosrts (exhorts) God keep us sound in the faith and send us health and a care to please God before all." She admonishes Be not speedy of speech, nor talk
suuddenly (suddenly), discrteion (discretion) requieth (requireth) and that soberly then..." If she has to descend to an actual object a basket of starwberries (strawberries) it is with c dark insintuat ons (insinuations). Greek and atin (Latin) come as easily to her pen as English. There is no gaity (gaiety), no freedom no familairty (familiarity) in this world. Fear of God, suspciion (suspicion) of man surround the writer as with the wlls (walls) of a dungeon. The wall may conceal a Lady Ann whois (who is)merry and gay; it may conceal must cobneceal (conceal) passion, laughter and sorrow; but no one can tell who it is that lives on the other side of the wall of formal langauge (language).
